There is much debate and discussion as to whether or not the information 
a=
pparently received in EVP sessions comes from within or from external
sourc=
es. The 2012 issue offers a unique opportunity to resolve this question.

S=
ome Mayan experts say that the notion that they Mayan calendar ends
in 2012=
 is in fact a misinterpretation of the facts; that the current Mayan
calend=
ar indeed ends in that year, but Mayan calendars continue on well
into the =
next millenium at least. If this is true the Mayans may have never
believed=
 everything would come to an end in the year we know as 2012.

The only rea=
l test is to wait until the end of 2012 and see what happens.
Let's be opti=
mistic and presume that nothing or little untoward indeed
occurs. What=C2=
=A0would this say about these, and similar communications?

One reasonable =
suggestion is that this would support the idea that the 
communications are=
 not from an external source, but are instead coming
from ourselves or at l=
east from other living beings. If the predictions turn 
out to be wrong, th=
is seems like convincing evidence that the source was
in fact misinformed. =
And while it is possible that discarnate entities are
playing tricks on us,=
 an equally reasonable interpretation is that we are
in fact the source at =
least of these communications, perhaps through 
some form of PK. 

As I hav=
e reported here before, there is good test data that suggests 
this is quit=
e possible in living persons. So this would be one more data 
point support=
ing the thesis that EVPs may in fact be the product of the 
living and not =
the dead.

It will be an interesting couple of years, no matter what - that=
 is certain.

I think part of the animosity between the scientis=
t/skeptic and the paranormalist/believer, is that they are speaking a diffe=
rent language, and often don=C3=A2=E2=82=AC=E2=84=A2t know it.



Both come=
 up with theories. =C3=82=C2=A0And these may lead to conclusions. =C3=82=C2=
=A0A scientist frames this as part of the scientific method, and expects a =
lot of work to be done between the theory and the conclusions. =C3=82=C2=A0=
A believer often starts with a theory, =C3=82=C2=A0and then states new thin=
gs based on that. =C3=82=C2=A0The scientist interprets the believer=C3=A2=
=E2=82=AC=E2=84=A2s statements as the believers =C3=A2=E2=82=AC=CB=9Cconclu=
sions=C3=A2=E2=82=AC=E2=84=A2, and is appalled at the lack of process that =
got the believer from theory to conclusion. =C3=82=C2=A0



The believer is=
 appalled at the scientist's closed mind. =C3=82=C2=A0But in fact, the beli=
ever did not mean their statements to actually be conclusions, in the scien=
tific sense. =C3=82=C2=A0=C3=82=C2=A0The believer thinks about their theori=
es, maybe tests them, and more often than not, comes up with new THEORIES. =
=C3=82=C2=A0But by not stating that these are theories, the scientist sees =
them as conclusions (since they seemed to flow from theory and testing). =
=C3=82=C2=A0And hence, the friction between these camps.



So I think both=
 parties share some of the blame. =C3=82=C2=A0The scientist assumes the bel=
iever understands the scientific method, and is making conclusions from the=
 scientific method, when the believer may really just be detailing more the=
ories. =C3=82=C2=A0The believer watches scientific-looking tv shows, uses s=
cientific-looking equipment, and uses scientific-sounding words like =C3=A2=
=E2=82=AC=CB=9Ctheory=C3=A2=E2=82=AC=E2=84=A2 and =C3=A2=E2=82=AC=CB=9Cevid=
ence=C3=A2=E2=82=AC=E2=84=A2, without realizing this casts them into the sc=
ientific method in the ears of the scientific community.



What to do? =C3=
=82=C2=A0I think if the scientist/skeptic more often asked things like =C3=
=A2=E2=82=AC=C5=93Are you sure of that, or is that a theory?=C3=A2=E2=82=AC=
=EF=BF=BD, and the paranormalist/believer used the word =C3=A2=E2=82=AC=CB=
=9Ctheory=C3=A2=E2=82=AC=E2=84=A2 a lot more in their proclamations, it wou=
ld go a long way toward less hostilities.
